block.p: Rights Groups Seek End Of Secret U.S. Detentions Six human rights groups released a list of 39 people they believe have been secretly imprisoned by the United States and whose whereabouts are unknown, calling on the Bush administration to abandon such detentions.

'Deranged' Man Leaps at Pope A man the Vatican described as ''clearly deranged'' sprang over a barricade and landed a yard or so behind Pope Benedict XVI as he rode in an uncovered popemobile through crowds at St. Peter's Square.

Opponents Arrested in Pakistan The Pakistani police have arrested more than 300 political party workers over the past few days in a crackdown before a protest planned against new government curbs on the news media, a government official acknowledged.

Palestinians Delay Israel Talks A meeting scheduled between the prime minister of Israel and the Palestinian president has been postponed over what appeared to be the issue of the conditions under which Israel would turn over tax revenues it collects for the Palestinians.
Tense Start to G-8 Meeting As the annual Group of 8 meeting began in Germany, the White House said it would hold firm against concrete targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Deal for Darfur Peacekeeping The United Nations and the African Union struck a tentative deal to end disagreement over the command of a 23,000-soldier joint peacekeeping force proposed for Darfur.

Technique Raises Hope Of Easing Stem Cell Debate Researchers have come closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patient's cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease. A1
Warning on Diabetes Drugs The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern.
Candidates to Skip Straw Poll Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain announced that they would skip participation in a key early test of candidate strength, the straw poll in Ames, Iowa.

DNA Links Found in 7 Diseases Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them.
Immigration Plan Survives The Senate signaled support for major provisions of a comprehensive immigration bill by rejecting many proposed amendments.

Inquiry on Loan Company Grows Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans has exposed ties between universities and lenders, said that he was broadening his investigation to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans, and whether they violate civil rights statutes.

9-Year-Old Makes Career Out of Video Games Victor M. De Leon III, a 9-year-old Long Island boy better known as Lil' Poison, is thought to be the world's youngest professional gamer. Victor will appear this weekend at a Major League Gaming event at the Meadowlands. A1
Missing Teenager Found A 15-year-old Connecticut girl who had been missing for nearly a year was found in the house of a business acquaintance of the girl's stepfather, the police said. B1
Project Lawsuit Dismissed A federal judge dismissed the most significant lawsuit against the Atlantic Yards development project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents. B3

China Reviews Food Rules Responding to concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs, China said that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections.

Jim Clark The former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed to the success of the voting-rights movement, he was 84. A33
Editorials: Looking for leadership; out from the ethical deep freeze; the inadequacy of civil unions; Lawrence Downes on ''silent amnesty'' and immigration.
Columns: Timothy Egan and Nicholas D. Kristof.
